It's quite tricky.

Well, come on to next year later, but let's now talk about 2024, we're at the halfway stage.
What is your overriding feeling as to how things have gone so far?
The overriding feeling is always the last feeling you have in a season, and at the moment,
we are not in a good time, and we are, we are struggling a lot more than the way the season started.
I think during this first for half of the season, we've had two parts, the first part,
which was very, very positive. As much as we still knew, we had some steps forward to do in terms
of performance. I think we were maximizing our potential every weekend, at the beginning of the
season, that was really a positive. Unfortunately, since we brought the upgrade on our car in Barcelona,
we faced some unexpected issues, which pushed us to actually be a bit more experimental on the
setup side to try and fix those issues. And when you do that, you have a bit less of consistency
throughout the weekend. You lose a little bit of path, which is what happened. You learn a huge
amount, which is also what happened, and that will be beneficial for the rest of the season.
However, you lose quite a lot of points along the way, so that was an ideal.
Now, we are just in the end of this process, and in Budapest, we managed to
maximize the potential of the car again, which was a good thing, but there's still the performance
that is lacking to our car, and we are working on that. From the outside looking in,
this has got 2022 vibes all over it, where, remember, 22, you started really strongly,
and then actually at Barcelona, it started to tail off again, didn't it?
I don't think so. I think it's very close to the situation we found ourselves in
Zanvort and Montsalasia in 23, where we sacrifice a little bit of the maximization of the weekend
in Zanvort and Montsat to understand, and to the big step forward after that. And I think that's
exactly the period of time we have gone through. Unfortunately, instead of being two races,
it was four races, which is longer than what I had wished, but it's been super beneficial for
the whole team to understand exactly the issue that we were facing. In 2022, I think it was
a bit less clear, and I don't think we got out of this phase knowing exactly where we had to work on.
So that's the worst you can have, when you don't maximize a result, but you get out of this
difficult time and it's not like you have very clear ideas. 23 and 24 was very different in that matter,
and I think it will help us a lot for the future. Right, so are you confident for the second half of
the year then? The only thing that changes compared to 23 is that we had a very quick fix in 23
to the issues we understood. We understood the issues. I really believe that we have a fix.
However, it's probably not short, short term, but not long term either. I cannot go too much into
details though. I mean, so is it a Ferrari thing or is it this specification of car thing?
That it seems to me red bull are the only ones who have been consistent with these regulations.
Everyone else at the front has had strong races and weak races, and where we went from the
amazing weekend you had in Monaco to Canada two weeks later. Why is it so difficult to tame these cars?
We cannot take that as an excuse. However, it's definitely a fact that apart from red bull,
I really feel like it's everybody in the paddock that is struggling to find that consistency,
and whenever you bring up grade performance upgrades, you always discover new things, new things,
that you didn't expect, that you didn't see on simulations, and that's not only us, but it's
everywhere in the paddock. But as you said, red bull managed to make it right since now the
beginning of those new regulations. So it cannot be an excuse and we need to be the best
inside the paddock and we are aware of it. So we are just focusing on ourselves and try to
try to become the best team out there. I mean, so do you find moments like this difficult because
you're long overdue, a consistent run of success. And how do you stop frustration creeping in?
By focusing on the present, I think whenever if you start to have expectations or
focusing on the wrong things frustration can arrive, to say that I'm happy in a situation like
that will be too lie. I'm not happy, but being frustrated is not the words. I'm very, very
motivated to try and turn the situation around. Unfortunately, it's been a bit too long that we have
been saying that as a team and we need to do that now, but yeah, it's not to think about that that
will help us, it's just to think about what are the issues at the moment and what we can do in our
power now to get better in the future. But that's the only thing we can focus on. How long do you
dwell on a bad weekend? I mean, they always say, don't you learn more from losing the winning?
You do, but you learn as well on winning especially again with those generation of cars because when
things are going right like in Monaco and everything ticks and yeah, everything just works out.
You also need to understand why it went so well on a weekend like this. So you learn in both ways,
but for sure, there's been quite a lot of unexpected things that we did not expect in the last few
upgrades that we brought and that we also learned from that. While we're talking about learning
and mentality, I'm reminded of a speech that Roger Federer gave earlier this year at Dartmouth
in the USA in which he talked about, you know, we're talking about a guy who had a lot of success,
20 Grand Slam victories. Yet he only won 54% of the points he played and he, the point he was making
to these students was that you, a point is only a point and you have to move on to the and focus
on the next point. And is that your approach to races good or bad? You have to focus on the next point?
This for sure, I think as an athlete but also as a team overall, I think there's something in
sport in general is that you are as good as your last performance and so you cannot rely on
how good of a momentum there's around you or how bad of a momentum there's around you. I think
the best thing you can do as an athlete is just to focus on yourself and to be as emotionally flat

But do you think you drove on another level at Monaco?

I'm always confident on race day. Even when I'm starting P12 or P11 in Canada and I know that we've
